text: you're looking pretty sexy Thanks hi
everyone
Anthony Pham tan oh here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new how to dress well
record what is this heart habit dress
will is the solo project of
singer-songwriter Tom crow who initially
exploded in the underground music world
as a pitchfork
favorite which he continues to be he was
applauded by them and many other
publications for his loafie experimental
approach to R&B contemporary R&B
personally I couldn't really follow suit
in the praise the recording of his debut
album to me was just unjustifiably
crummy and distorted I was finding some
redeeming factors in the songs
themselves but they're really shrill
distortion that many of them were
covered in and kind of made it hard to
listen although there was an EP who
followed this album up with that
featured some orchestral instrumentation
underneath his vocals which I thought
was very beautiful but on Tom's next
album which I liked more he really
redeemed himself on the recording
quality side of things the
instrumentation his vocals sounded
really nice clean this album brought a
series of tracks that were really
ethereal and syrupy and a few that were
kind of up being catchy too but to me
stripping away the low five production
and the distortion made so many more
things clearer about how to dress well
namely that the songwriting was just
okay and that Tom Krell is not really
the most versatile of vocalists in a
genre where vocal virtuosity is kind of
emphasized and as far as this new LP
goes much of what was the case on total
loss continues on to what is this hard
with a few exceptions for one there are
more acoustic guitars on this record
Tom's voice doesn't sound quite as
reverb soaked it's much more close and
upfront this is I think a slightly more
intimate record for how to dress well
however at the end of the day this album
me sort of like total loss ended up
being kind of hit or miss liking some
tracks disliking others being on the
fence with much of what was brought to
the table a lot of the time it's not
like Tom is really writing bold
captivating songs or delivering them
with a top-notch vocal still Tom sort of
sings in this very whimper e weak
falsetto I guess in a sense it's a
motive but it kind of gets stale for me
after a while and the instrumentation
even on the more upbeat track seems too
polite to move me out of the neutral
emotional state I was in before I put
the album on and moments on this record
that I do think are gripping like the
opener where Tom is singing over these
really nimble beautiful acoustic guitar
melodies are really developed beyond
anything that I'm hearing at the
beginning of the track it feels more
like a motif even though it's about four
minutes long but over the course of the
song it only delivers this middle ground
of passion and beauty and when this
record does get loud sometimes it sounds
really messy it seems that tom is still
not past delivering subpar production on
some of his tracks like the song
childhood faith in love which sounds
pretty nice up to the point where these
really goofy rhythms and vocal samples
enter the picture and it kind of sounds
like panda bear of Animal Collective
came in and did some guest production
and the end result was just the song
precious love as well which feels kind
of like a demo with how thin all the
instrumentation sounds but melodically I
do think it's one of the better Tunes on
the record there's some straightforward
concise songs in the tracklist on this
thing like what you wanted which seems
like a very simple slow kind of funky
80s era R&B pop fusion something I could
see playing on the radio back then if it
were actually as catchy and snappy and
as enthusiastic as R&B music from that
era this is why tracks like repeat
pleasure don't really do it for me
Tom Krell doesn't live up to the
standards of the R&B music he very
clearly borrows from not to mention
there are some pretty awful fake
handclaps all over this song that are
pretty gross the instrumentals on this
record are
underwhelming and unexcited and as our
the Vogel's but today because Tom
Krell's music isn't as snappy or as
hard-hitting as the commercial R&B music
that we remember from these decades it's
seen as novel and is different and as
exciting or even passionate and I do
think there are tracks that that that
are passionate and are enjoyable like
the song face again which has this
massive bass line some glassy
synthesizers and one of the most winning
hooks on the entire LP it's really one
of the most stunningly passionate
moments on the entire record and then
there's the song poor Cyril which is one
of these moments of orchestral beauty
where the strings and just the
atmosphere of the song really brings it
to a whole new level of gorgeousness
for this record personally I find myself
gravitating the most toward the softer
and more subtle and more slow building
tracks off of this record like the songs
I just mentioned or see you fall or a
power which has these very beautiful
cascading piano melodies falling all
over one another like slinkys going down
the stairs
not every slow building track actually
has a beautiful awesome finish or an
interesting journey like words I don't
remember or the closer but I do find
these songs so much more fitting and
engaging but there isn't much more on
this record that sticks out to me is
like a true favorite or a serious
highlight again to me this album in a
lot of ways is in the same vein as total
loss a little more intimate the beats
are a little more diverse there's
definitely an increase in acoustic
instrumentation Tom Krell's voice is
more upfront but I just don't see his
songwriting as memorable
especially with lyrics on the track very
best friend which really brings the
entire record down to a very very corny
low even though I think Tom takes more
risks than he did on total loss I think
he ends up with an even larger mixed bag
of results I'm feeling a strong five to
a light six on this LP transition if
you've given the
Recker - listen what did you think of it
did you love it did you hate it why what
do you think I should review next and
